The class action lawsuit filed by the pilots association against Southwest Airlines should have every one of you cheering and paying close attention. These pilots aren’t just collectively standing up fo their own rights - at this point they are representing all of us fighting for medical freedom. It is only one tiny step from mandates tor employees to mandates for passengers to mandates for all civil and commercial activities. Thank you to these brave pilots and the attorneys representing them in court. Link to the lawsuit is here - as well as the contact information for the attorneys representing. Send them a heartfelt thank you and if you’re so inclined, a financial contribution to the upcoming legal fees. A victory for these pilots would be a victory for us all.

LUV isn't going out of business, but they will be losing money for another year. What's a good price to buy?

Key Points • Southwest Airlines reported a disappointing (but expected) loss for the third quarter earlier this week. • The airline giant is bracing for an even bigger loss in the fourth quarter. • Other airlines have proven more nimble than Southwest over the past year, making it hard to justify Southwest Airlines' valuation premium.For much of its 50-year history, Southwest Airlines (NYSE:LUV) has been one of the most profitable airlines in the world. Indeed, from 1973 to 2019, the company put together a string of 47 consecutive annual profits: an amazing feat in such a volatile business. Most of its main competitors went bankrupt over that period (some more than once).However, Southwest Airlines has posted subpar results since the COVID-19 pandemic upended the airline industry last year. The carrier continued that trend this week, reporting a loss for the third quarter and projecting an even bigger loss for the current quarter.

• Evercore ISI analyst Duane Pfenningwerth downgraded Southwest Airlines Co (NYSE: LUV) to In-Line from Outperform and lowered the price target to $48 (an upside of 0.51%) from $55. • Given his view of longer-lasting rebuild cost pressures and his opinion that Street expectations are "overly optimistic," he sees muted valuation upside. • As a response to insufficient staffing and recent operational challenges, Southwest is "logically" slowing its growth rate in Q4 and Q1, but ramping hiring while slowing growth and increasing capital intensity makes it tougher to argue for the stock as a standout versus better executing alternative airlines, Pfenningwerth notes.
